comments.body: They could only be triggered underground but effect the land above them. I imagine it would send mobs into a panicked state, items would pop out of item frames, crops and plants may be destroyed, etc
This would be a good alternative to an earthquake as it wouldn't really destroy anything, just affect how the world works
The panicked mob state would be awesome

Tremors would be better as a sound effect that happens similar to the ominous noises you hear in the dark. It would make caving more immersive to hear caves crackling and quaking like the earth is shifting to simulate tectonic activity.
Another idea for bedrock and java is that they all get along
Wow
Please don't take this personally, but this doesn't fit in Minecraft.

On the contrary, I think this would be cool. Many people want blocks that can change colors. This block could be an ingredient to make a block that changes into more colors depending on redstone events

I think this is fantastic and I love it! I was expecting some weird fantasy thing, but this is actually a good idea that would help people learn more about the world we live in. Heck, I didn't even know this was a thing until right now! I'm already learning! And in response to CreeperDoge75, it does too fit in minecraft! Believe me, there are things that don't fit, but this isn't one of them. This would be a fantastic and educational addition to minecraft, and the chocolate dirt (Is that what it's called? Can we call it that?) would be a great addition with it's weather detecting properties. Just now, I thought of a mechanism that uses observers to detect when it rains using the chocolate dirt, and then pushes lightning rods up to the roof, for when people don't want to see a lightning rod on the roof but also don't want their creation destroyed by lightning. I'm sure there are more applications too! And maybe, just for fun, they could have a small chance of dropping cocoa beans when you dig the dirt. Maybe? Maybe not. Never mind, that's probably too weird. But yes! I agree with this biome wholeheartedly!

If I were to add this to the game, I'd add two new blocks called Limestone and Limestone Soil. Chocolate Hills are actually made up of grass-covered limestone. The grass turns chocolate-brown when it's dry season and green when it's rainy season. In Minecraft, the Limestone Soil should be brown in default and green when it's raining. The new Limestone block could be used as just a building block like Granite, Andesite, and Diorite with all their polished variants!

(I appreciate the comments though thanks!)
Hmmmmmm what an interesting idea

Items aren‚Äôt animated without texture packs but blocks are, Magma blocks and sea lanterns are a few blocks that are animated in your hot bar (even though it‚Äôs barely noticeable) so it makes sense for sculk sensors to be animated too,
Redstone current only flows through an amethyst block while you are mining it. Or perhaps it could stop flowing when you mine it...

I know its not realistic and does not entirely make sense but what if it slowly builds up a charge and then discharges that signal. so when redstone is connected to the amethyst every 20 ticks the redstone signal strength is added until the amethysts charge is 30 which then releases a redstone pulse of 30.

it would be useful for making timers and counters and maybe compariters outputs whatever signal strength the device is currently on.

once one of my lighters broke, so i took the piezoelectric spark thingy out of it,

i wanted to see what it felt like when i zapped myself with it, and it hurt.

so maybe it could be turned into a weapon of some kind.

like maybe if you put a bow and an amethyst shard in a crafting table, it could make some kind of short range zapping weapon
Mabye even a zapping arrow.
Mabye even a zapping arrow.

My idea is to add the four-leaf clover soup, which I would do is that when consuming it it would give you luck for 3 seconds and at the time of killing a mob or mining a mineral it could multiply it, although the possibility is 1 / 100, the clover could give you an indication that you are near the mansion, they spawn between 2 and 3 and its crafting is: a clover, a mushroom, a red mushroom and a bowl
I don't see a point in adding clover soup, but four leaf clovers (much rarer) should be the ingredient for a potion of luck. (currently unbrewable)
A cool idea, but why would you want to keep Piglins and Hoglins on the overworld?

hoglins may or may not be of use in the overworld, I am not too familiar with the details...however, you can trade with piglins but not when they are zombified. Some people may find it more convenient to trade in the overworld and I believe some creative ideas can spark from this...

Not forgetting that the atmosphere in the nether and the overworld is different, so builds will have to change to complement the surroundings too, thus this would most likely give rise to new builds and overall improve gameplay...

As I said earlier I do not know too much of the intricate details of the game so there may be an attack difference for the hoglin and it's zombified variant, thus there may be people preferring to use the hoglin instead if it was possible for things like mini-games or fun traps in multiplayer worlds. This too also would give rise to more creative ideas...
Would this be designed to look like shingles on roofs? Would it fall when walked on or hit? If so, avalanches could have similar mechanics
Would there be any mechanics to this block?
They would be designed to look like shingles, but triangular instead of rectangular.  There would be no mechanics to this block.

wool can be soaked with water

New block: Soaked wool

I think all blocks, as far as I know, drip water particles when there is a water source above them. I don't think any blocks besides dripstone should drip water because then it takes away from its uniqueness, unless of course everyone is fine with them having the ability to fall and injure players as well as drip lava
i would think this could be implemented as a worse version of dripstone. being able to drip water but not lava.
I was thinking that since you dry mud with dripstone to get clay, the dripping water should be able to fill a cauldron like lava does.  Just seems to be a mechanic that is visually there already.
That's not how dripstones work.

how does the spawns but starts to take damage work? is it within 5 seconds of spawning?

I suggested malachite as copper ore, since it is in real life.  If copper ore was mined with silk touch, it drops copper or blocks, which smelt into copper ingots.  If mined with a regular pickaxe, it drops malachite chunks that can be smelted into copper or crafted into malachite blocks, which have the distinctive green banding and maybe even hints of chrysacolla and azurite.  It would be a decorative block which could also be smelted to produce copper.  Malachite is actually used in some palaces as a decorative material.
it could give the telescope a higher zoom
